exercises.name: Thought Record
exercises.description: A structured way to examine and challenge negative thoughts by writing down the situation, your thoughts, emotions, evidence for/against, and a balanced alternative thought.
steps: Describe the situation that triggered your negative thought
Write down the automatic negative thought
Identify the emotions you felt and rate their intensity (0-100)
List evidence that supports the thought
List evidence that contradicts the thought
Write a more balanced, realistic thought
Re-rate your emotions after this exercise
exercises.tips: Be specific and objective. Treat yourself like you would a friend facing the same situation.

exercises.name: Evidence Examination
exercises.description: Challenge a negative thought by examining the actual evidence for and against it, like a detective or scientist.
steps: Write down the negative thought clearly
Ask: What evidence supports this thought being TRUE?
Ask: What evidence suggests this thought might be FALSE or exaggerated?
Based on all evidence, write a more accurate thought
exercises.tips: Stick to facts, not feelings. Only include evidence that would hold up in court.

exercises.name: Perspective Shift
exercises.description: View the situation from different angles to gain a more balanced perspective.
steps: Describe your current thought/interpretation
How would a supportive friend view this situation?
How might you view this in 5 years?
What would you tell a friend who had this thought?
Write a new perspective based on these viewpoints
exercises.tips: Imagine actually having these conversations. What specific words would you or others use?

exercises.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
exercises.description: A sensory awareness technique to bring you back to the present moment when feeling overwhelmed.
steps: Name 5 things you can SEE around you
Name 4 things you can TOUCH or feel
Name 3 things you can HEAR
Name 2 things you can SMELL
Name 1 thing you can TASTE
exercises.tips: Take your time with each sense. Really notice the details of what you're experiencing.

exercises.name: Box Breathing
exercises.description: A simple breathing technique to calm your nervous system and reduce anxiety.
steps: Breathe IN slowly for 4 counts
HOLD your breath for 4 counts
Breathe OUT slowly for 4 counts
HOLD empty for 4 counts
Repeat 4-6 times
exercises.tips: Find a comfortable seated position. If 4 counts feels too long, start with 3.

exercises.name: Behavioral Experiment
exercises.description: Test out negative predictions by trying something and observing the actual outcome.
steps: Identify a specific negative prediction you're making
Rate how strongly you believe it (0-100%)
Design a small experiment to test this prediction
Carry out the experiment
Record what actually happened
Compare the outcome to your prediction
Re-rate your belief in the original prediction
exercises.tips: Start small. Choose something low-stakes to test first.

exercises.name: Three Good Things
exercises.description: Counter the brain's negativity bias by deliberately noticing positive experiences.
steps: Write down 3 good things that happened today (big or small)
For each one, note why it happened
Reflect on how each one made you feel
Consider how you contributed to making it happen
exercises.tips: They don't need to be big things. A nice cup of coffee or a friendly smile counts.

exercises.name: Self-Compassion Break
exercises.description: Respond to difficult thoughts with kindness rather than criticism.
steps: Acknowledge: 'This is a moment of suffering'
Recognize common humanity: 'Suffering is part of being human. Others feel this way too.'
Offer yourself kindness: Place your hand on your heart and say something kind to yourself
Ask: 'What do I need right now?' and try to provide it
exercises.tips: Use a warm, gentle tone with yourself. Imagine comforting a good friend.

exercises.name: Should to Could
exercises.description: Transform rigid 'should' statements into flexible preferences.
steps: Write down your 'should' statement
Rewrite it using 'I would prefer...' or 'I could...'
Notice how the new statement feels different
Consider what options this new framing opens up
exercises.tips: Shoulds create pressure; preferences create possibility. Notice the difference in your body.

exercises.name: Responsibility Pie
exercises.description: Visually divide responsibility for an outcome among all contributing factors.
steps: Describe the negative outcome you're blaming yourself for
List ALL factors that contributed (other people, circumstances, timing, etc.)
Assign a percentage to each factor (must total 100%)
Draw a pie chart showing the distribution
Notice what percentage is realistically yours
exercises.tips: List external factors first before assigning your share. Be honest about things outside your control.
